titleStmt.title: Picture fuzzy normalized projection-based VIKOR method for the risk evaluation of construction project

analytic.title: Picture fuzzy normalized projection-based VIKOR method for the risk evaluation of construction project

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.head: Highlights
div.p:  The risk evaluation of construction projects is described as an MCDM problem with the PFNs to comprise the complex nature of the selection process.  A picture fuzzy normalized projection model is proposed to overcome the limitations of the extant picture fuzzy projection model.  In order to reduce the randomness of subjective weight, a picture fuzzy entropy weight method is A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T 2 introduced to obtain an objective weight vector of criteria.  Picture fuzzy normalized projection-based VIKOR method is developed to rank risk factors of construction project considering the compromise among criteria.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The complex and uncertain risks of construction project have been gradually increased because of the development of the scale of construction project. Consequently, focusing on risk management in construction project is necessary. Risk management [1] comprises risk identification, risk evaluation, risk response, and risk supervision [2]. Among them, risk evaluation [3] is a process of prioritizing risks for further analysis and can be viewed as a multi-criteria decision-making (MCDM) problem. Because of the limited resources and numerous risk factors, it is essential to identify the priority of risks through risk evaluation. In addition, when the priority of risks has been identified, risk response can focus on coping the serious, urgent and prioritized risks and adopting appropriate strategies against other risks. Through the scientific and effective risk response, the influence of risk can be significantly reduced and the efficiency of risk management can be improved.
Therefore, risk evaluation is a significant component of risk management, and many studies have investigated it [4].

Uncertain information of risk factors exists in the different stages of the construction project because of the uncertainties of political, market, natural environment, management, as well as the complexity of the project itself. To describe the fuzzy and uncertain decision-making information, fuzzy sets (FSs) [5] were introduced. FSs are characterized by a membership function and have been used to solve risk evaluation problems [6,7] and other MCDM problems [8,9]. Based on FSs, intuitionistic fuzzy sets (IFSs) [10] were introduced, which are characterized by membership degree and non-membership degree. Many researchers have studied risk evaluation under intuitionistic fuzzy environment [11,12]. However, FSs and IFSs cannot satisfy the situations where we face opinions that involve various types of answers, such as yes, abstain, no, and refusal. Thus, Coung and Kreinovich [13] proposed picture fuzzy sets (PFSs), which are extensions of FSs and IFSs. PFSs are characterized by the degrees of positive membership, neutral membership, negative membership and refusal membership. Obviously, using PFSs to describe the uncertain information are more realistic and accurate than FSs and IFSs.

Since the introduction of PFSs, many scholars have applied them into the picture fuzzy clustering [14,15]. Son [16,17] described the reasons and advantages of using PFSs, and he proposed a generalized picture distance for picture fuzzy clustering. Recently, studies have been developed on the MCDM method with picture fuzzy information [18]. Wei [19] first introduced picture fuzzy cross-entropy and utilized it to deal with MCDM problem. Thereafter, Wei et al. [20,21] defined the operations of picture fuzzy numbers (PFNs) and proposed picture 2-tuple linguistic aggregation operator and Bonferroni mean operator based on the defined operations. However, the proposed operations of PFNs cannot satisfy the constraint that the sum of the degrees of PFNs must not exceed 1. Subsequently, Wang et al. [22] proposed some geometric aggregation operators based on new operations of PFNs and applied them into MCDM method. In addition, Wei et al. [23] introduced a picture fuzzy projection model to handle the MCDM problem. However, this model exists some limitations that will be described in Section 2.2.

The concept of projection model considers the distance and included angle between two evaluative values. Therefore, projection model has been successfully and extensively used to replace distance in various fuzzy environments [24][25][26][27]. Furthermore, many researchers studied the integrated method on the basis of projection. Gao and Liu [28] integrated prospect theory and projection, and proposed a new prospect projection MCDM method for interval intuitionistic fuzzy numbers. Sun et al. [29] proposed a projection-based MABAC (multi-attributive border approximation area comparison) method and applied it to patients' prioritization. Wang and Han [30] introduced a grey relation projection method with respect to the multi-criteria group decision-making problem under the interval-valued intuitionistic trapezoidal environment.

Weight vector of criteria is also an important component of MCDM problem. Formulated in terms of probability theory, Shannon [31] proposed the concept of entropy, which is a measure of uncertainty in information. To date, fuzzy entropy [32] and intuitionistic fuzzy entropy [33] have attracted attentions from researchers in the theoretical and practical realms. The fuzzy entropy weight method [34] was proposed based on entropy to obtain the objective weights. The construction project is a large and complex project, and the weight vector of criteria may have great influence on the final result. To take into account the important role of criteria weights, reducing the randomness, the entropy weight method is suitable for obtaining an objective weight vector of criteria.

In recent years, an increasing number of studies concerns the MCDM methods, such as Technique for Order Performance by Similarity to Ideal Solution (TOPSIS) [35], Vlsekriterijumska Optimizacija I Kompromisno Resenje (VIKOR) [36], an acronym in Portuguese for interactive and multi-criteria decision-making (TODIM) [37], elimination and choice expressing reality (ELECTRE) [38], and qualitative flexible multiple criteria method (QUALIFLEX) [39]. These methods can effectively solve MCDM problems from different angles. The VIKOR method was developed by Opricovic [40], and this method can be used to determine a compromise solution under a set of criteria based on a particular measure of closeness to the ideal solution [41]. Generally, determining a risk factor that simultaneously satisfies all the criteria is generally difficult. So, obtaining a good compromise solution through VIKOR method is preferred. To handle fuzzy and uncertain problems, various fuzzy VIKOR methods were proposed [42,43]. Meanwhile, a series of integrated methods based on VIKOR method were investigated, for instance, FAHP-VIKOR method [44] and fuzzy GRA-VIKOR techniques [45]. In addition, Mardani et al. [46] conducted a literature review of the development of VIKOR method and determined that the VIKOR method is mainly organized into 15 application areas, such as manufacturing, construction management, risk and financial management, tourism management, and supply chain.
PFNs can describe fuzzy and uncertain information involved in practical decision-making problems, and
div.formula: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: PFNs can mitigate information loss. However, studies of risk evaluation with picture fuzzy information are relatively fewer. Compared with distance, projection is a more comprehensive measure to describe the difference or similarity between two evaluations. Nevertheless, the extant projection model of PFSs has some limitations. Entropy weight method is an effective way to calculate objective weight. However, no study has defined the picture fuzzy entropy. In addition, traditional fuzzy VIKOR utilized distance to represent the closeness to the ideal solution, replacing distance with projection may be more appropriate. But, no study has integrated projection and VIKOR method under picture fuzzy environment.

Based on the aforementioned analysis, the purposes of this study are to overcome existing limitations and develop a comprehensive MCDM framework. The details of these purposes are as follows. First, PFSs are used to describe the risk evaluation information in the decision-making process to mitigate information loss.

Second, a picture fuzzy normalized projection (PFNP) model is proposed to overcome the limitations of the extant projection model of PFSs. Third, the entropy weight method is proposed to calculate the weight vector of criteria. Then, an integrated MCDM method is established based on PFNP model and fuzzy VIKOR method. Finally, the effectiveness and flexibility of the proposed method are further verified through a case study, sensitivity analysis and comparative analysis.

The rest of this study is organized as follows. Section 2 briefly reviews the basic concepts of PFSs and the extant projection model of PFSs. Section 3 proposes a PFNP model to overcome the limitations of the extant picture fuzzy projection model. Then, a PFNP-based difference measurement is introduced to describe the difference between two PFNs. Section 4 constructs a comprehensive MCDM framework of picture fuzzy normalized projection-based VIKOR (PFNP-VIKOR) method for risk evaluation. Section 5 presents a case study on the risk evaluation of a green construction project, and performs a sensitivity analysis. Furthermore, Section 5 presents a comparative analysis with other methods. Lastly, Section 6 presents the conclusion of this study.

div.head: Preliminaries
div.p: This section reviews basic concepts of PFSs and the extant projection model of PFSs. Meanwhile, the limitations of the extant projection model of PFSs are identified.

div.head: Picture fuzzy sets
div.p: PFSs are proposed as an extension of FSs and IFSs. Thus, PFSs express the evaluation information more accurately and comprehensively than FSs and IFSs when decision makers (DMs) face opinions involving four types of answers. The definition of PFS is described in the following.

div.head: Picture fuzzy projection model
div.p: Picture fuzzy projection model considers the distance and included angle between two PFNs. The extant picture fuzzy projection model was proposed by Wei et al. [23] and it was applied to the MCDM problem.
The definition of the extant picture fuzzy projection model and limitations are presented as follows.

div.head: Normalized projection model and normalized projection-based difference measurement of PFSs
div.p: In this section, a PFNP model is proposed to overcome the aforementioned limitations of the extant picture fuzzy projection. In order to describe the difference between two PFSs, a PFNP-based difference measurement is introduced.

div.head: Picture fuzzy normalized projection-based difference measurement

div.head: Framework of picture fuzzy normalized projection-based VIKOR method for risk evaluation
div.p: In this section, a MCDM framework is constructed based on the PFNP-VIKOR method for risk factor evaluation with picture fuzzy information. Then, the framework of PFNP-VIKOR method for risk evaluation is presented in Figure 1.
Phase I: Obtain decision-making information.

The purpose of Phase I is to obtain a normalized decision matrix of risk evaluation information based on the invited experts. Taking into account the uncertainty and fuzziness of risk, the description of expert opinion will be comprehensive and appropriate with picture fuzzy information. Therefore, the risk evaluation information of this framework is represented with picture fuzzy information.
Step 1: Acquire and collect evaluation.
expresses the refusal membership degree.
For example, suppose the value of risk factor A under the criterion 1 C .
Given the limitations in the background knowledge of experts, they can selectively provide an evaluation to ensure the authority and correctness of the evaluation.
Step 2: Normalize the decision matrix.
The decision matrix has two types of criteria, namely benefit criteria and cost criteria. The evaluation need , , , . , , ,

div.p: Phase II: Determine the weight vector of criteria.

This Phase puts forward the definition of picture fuzzy entropy, and then, an entropy weight method of PFSs is proposed to calculate the weight vector of criteria. Before introducing the entropy weight method, the relevant definitions of picture fuzzy entropy are presented in the following. Thus, a function En:

div.p: Then, the steps of entropy weight measure are introduced as follows.
Step 1: Calculate the value of entropy for each criterion.
The picture fuzzy entropy value j En of the criterion j C is calculated using Eq. ( 22).
Step 2: Compute the weight vector of criteria.

The objective weight j w of criterion j C can be obtained based on the value of entropy and Eq. ( 23). Opricovic [40] first introduced the VIKOR method, which can obtain the compromising solution by considering the maximum group utility of the majority and the minimum of the individual regret of the opponent. The extant fuzzy VIKOR method utilizes the distance measurement to describe the difference between objects. However, the distance ignores the influence of the included angle between two objects, whereas the PFNP model can overcome this shortcoming. To compensate for the inadequacy in the extant VIKOR method, the PFNP model is utilized to replace the picture distance and the PFNP-VIKOR method is proposed to determine the rank order of risk factors. This phase involves the following steps.
Step 1: Determine the positive-ideal and negative ideal values for each criterion.
The positive-ideal and negative-ideal values are determined as follows:

div.p: Step 2: Calculate the group utility and individual regret based on PFNP.

In traditional fuzzy VIKOR method, distance is utilized to calculate the group utility and individual regret values. However, in order to comprehensively calculate them, the PFNP model is utilized to replace the picture distance. Therefore, the group utility i S and individual regret i R can be calculated based on the PFNP model using Eqs. ( 26) and (27).

div.p: Step 3: Calculate the VIKOR index.

div.head: Case study and results discussion
div.p: In recent years, the Chinese Ministry of Construction proposed the guidance of "building a resource-saving and environment-friendly society." The Chinese government prompted constructors to apply the concept of a "green building" into the construction industry. A green building can maximize resources (e.g., energy conservation, land, water, and materials) to protect the environment and reduce pollution. This concept can provide people an architecture with a healthy, applicable, and efficiently used space, as well as with the characteristic of a harmonious coexistence with nature. However, green building is a process that involves uncertainty and fuzzy risks.
div.formula: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: This case study involves a green building construction project in China. The project management team aims to determine whether the risks are prioritized to guarantee the quality, safety, and timely completion of the construction project. Thus, this management team invites 10 relevant experts from the expert databases system of Architectural Society of China to evaluate the risk factors. The expert had to satisfy two criteria before being selected. First, they need having abundant work experience in the construction industry of China. Second, they gained an in-depth knowledge through involving in the management of a green building construction projects. Then, the characteristics of the selected experts are summarized in Table 1. In addition, all reports, contracts, historical information, and other resourceful documents are used to identify and evaluate the risk factors in this project.

div.head: Results
div.p: In Phase I, seven key risk factors, which are based on the root causes of risks in the green building construction project, are adopted by consulting the relevant data and experts. The seven risk factors are denoted by  

, C ). After expert assessment, Table 3 presents the project risk evaluation matrix under the picture fuzzy environment. In this case study, when a risk factor has high probability of risk occurrence, high degree of influence, high degree of unpredictability, and high degree of urgency, the ranking order of the risk factor has priority. Thus, the four criteria are all benefit criteria in the risk evaluation problem, the normalization is unnecessary. In other words, the normalized decision matrix is same as Table 3.

( 22) (See the second row of Table 4). Thereafter, the objective weight j w of criterion j C can be calculated based on the value of j En and Eq. ( 23) (See the third row of 24) and ( 25), which are   0.9,0,0 , 0.8,0,0 , 0.9,0,0 , 0.8,0.1,0 ,

div.head: 5.2.Sensitivity analysis
div.p: The purpose of this subsection is to discuss the influence of the parameter v on the ranking orders. The value of v in Eq. ( 28) represents the weight of the decision mechanism of maximum group utility. If , then the decision mechanism is determined by consensus. In risk evaluation, DM can choose different values of v according to their preference, and obtain different ranking results. Figure 2 presents the corresponding ranking order and the changing tendency of the ranking order of each risk factor with the value of parameter v from 0 to 1, respectively.

As shown in Figure 2, the ranking orders of seven risk factors are not at all influenced by the value of v, and the highest risk factor is consistently risk 6 A . The result indicates that the obtained ranking orders of the proposed method are robust and reliable. In addition, the ranking order of risk 4 A moves down as the value of v increase. This reveals that risk 4 A has a higher level of risk when DM are inclined to maximum group utility. In contrast, the ranking orders of 1 A and 3 A move up as the value of v increase, indicating that they has higher level of risks when minimum individual regret is considered as important.

div.head: Comparative analysis
div.p: This subsection aims at verifying the feasibility of the proposed methods compared with several relevant methods. The comparative analysis consists of two cases as follows.

Case 1: This case aims at proving the efficiency of the proposed PFNP model and PFNP-VIKOR method with the numerical example [22] and the case study as our study, respectively. The details of the comparative methods are described as follows.

Considering the aggregation operator is one of the most widely used tool in MCDM methods, the first comparative method is an aggregation operator, namely, picture fuzzy weighted geometric (PFWG) operator
div.formula: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: proposed by Wang et al. [22]. To verify the proposed methods are superior to the extant projection model of PFSs, the second comparative method is the extant picture fuzzy projection model [23]. Wei et al. [23] proposed the extant projection model and applied the projection model to measure the similarity degree between PFN and the positive ideal solution. Taking into account distance and projection are equivalent in behavior, that is, they can reflect the difference or similarity between two values. The third comparative method is picture fuzzy Hamming distance (PFHD) measure proposed by Cuong and Kreinovich [13]. The distance value between a PFN and the positive ideal solution is denoted by ( , )

Then, the value of Then, Table 7 presents the comparative methods' ranking orders together with the proposed PFPN model and the proposed PFNP-VIKOR method based on the same numerical example [22] and the same case study as our study. With the numerical example [22], the ranking orders are same except for the extant projection model [23]. The results validate the feasibility of the proposed PFPN model and the proposed PFNP-VIKOR method. With the same case study as our study, despite slight difference in the ranking orders, the best alternative and the worst alternative obtained by the five methods are still 6 A and 1 A , respectively. The results also can prove the efficiency of the proposed methods to some extent. The reasons for this difference are presented as follows.

PFWG operator is an aggregation operator, and the result of PFWG operator is susceptible to the operations and comparison method. PFHD method is a distance measure, compared with projection method, distance ignores the influence of the the included angle between two evaluative values. The extant projection model of PFSs [23] has some limitations explained in Section 2. In this case, in order to further prove efficiency and feasibility of the proposed PFNP-VIKOR method, we compare our method with the traditional fuzzy VIKOR method with the same case study as our study. In the traditional fuzzy VIKOR methods, distance measures are mainly utilized to describe the closeness to the idea solution. Hence, we proposed the picture fuzzy Hamming distance-based VIKOR (PFHD-VIKOR) method. The only difference between the PFHD-VIKOR method and the proposed PFNP-VIKOR method is that PFHD-VIKOR method uses Eqs. ( 30) and ( 31) to calculate the group utility i S and individual regret i R , where p d is the distance value calculated by PFHD measure [13].

div.p: Table 8 exhibits the ranking orders and the highest risk of the two methods with different parameter v under the same case study as our study and Figure 3 shows the resulting values i Q of the two methods.
As shown in Table 8, it is obvious that despite slight difference in the ranking of risk factors 1 A , 3 A and 4

A , the ranking orders of other risk factors generated by the two methods are same. The result indicates the efficiency and feasibility of the proposed PFNP-VIKOR method to some extent. While, the highest risk factor obtained by the proposed PFNP-VIKOR method is only one ( 6 A ), but two compromise highest risk factors ( 6 A and 7 A ) are obtained by PFHD-VIKOR method. The main reason is that the PFHD-VIKOR method disregards the included angle between the two PFNs, whereas the proposed method considers this aspect. Therefore, the proposed PFNP-VIKOR method can obtained more accurate highest risk factor than PFHD-VIKOR method. In summary, the proposed method effectively and flexibly confronts the risk evaluation and other MCDM problems. The advantage of the proposed method can be presented as follows. First, the proposed PFNP-VIKOR method is not susceptible to the operations and comparison method. Second, the proposed method considers the distance and the included angle between two PFNs. Finally, the proposed method considers DM's compromises, and DMs can flexibly choose the weight of maximum group utility based on their own preference and the properties of project itself. Thus, the proposed PFNP-VIKOR method is more stable and applicable than other MCDM methods.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In this paper, a fuzzy MCDM framework for risk evaluation has been developed with picture fuzzy information. PFNs have been utilized to describe the uncertain and fuzziness information of risk factors.

Subsequently, the limitations of the extant projection model of PFSs have been identified. And the PFNP model has been proposed to overcome the limitations of the extant picture fuzzy projection model. Moreover, the entropy weight method has been proposed based on the defined picture fuzzy entropy to calculate the objective weights of criteria. Finally, the PFNP-VIKOR method has been developed to determine the ranking order of risk factors by considering the conflict of criteria. In addition, a case study, sensitivity analysis and comparative analysis have been conducted to prove the practicality, flexibility and feasibility of the proposed framework.

However, in this study, the interrelationships among the criteria are ignored. Researchers can devote themselves to improving this method in future work to overcome this defect. Meanwhile, risk evaluation is a complex endeavor, but in this study, we only consider the partial process to simplify the procedure.
Accordingly, a detailed and comprehensive study can be constructed in the future.

2 and the result obtained with the numerical example futher illustrates the unreliable of the extant projection model. In addition, although the proposed PFNP model has more advantages than PFWG operator, PFHD method and the extant projection model of PFSs, it does not consider DM's compromises. Compared with other methods, the proposed PFNP-VIKOR method not only consider the distance and the included angle between two PFNs, and DMs can flexibly choose the weight of maximum group utility based on their own preference and the properties of project itself.

figure.head: Figure 3 5 A , and 7 A
figure.figDesc: reveals that to an extent, the resulting values i Q obtained by the proposed method are similar to those values obtained by PFHD-VIKOR method. The result also can demonstrate the feasibility of the proposed method. In addition, the values of 3 A and 5 A obtained by PFHD-VIKOR method are larger than the values obtained by PFNP-VIKOR method. While the values of 7 A obtained by PFHD-VIKOR method are smaller than the values obtained by PFNP-VIKOR method. Thus, the influences of included angle of risk factors 3 A , is greater than other risk factors. It also can demonstrates the included angle will affect the final resulting values i Q , and it can not be ignored. Thus, projection is more superior than distance.
